subject: RE: [junit] Re: What's wrong with using inner classes for  tests?
msgSnippet: ... The Java language only exists by virtue of its definition in the official language specification.  Java s not very arbitrary.  I think it was appropriate
messageBody:
> From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
>
> Guys, when it gets to the point where you're arguing over
> definitions, stop. Definitions are arbitrary. You agree on the
> concepts. Relax.

The Java language only exists by virtue of its definition in the official
language specification. Java's not very arbitrary. I think it was
appropriate to refer (and defer) to the spec.

For the inner vs. nested distinction though, I think it's an unfortunate and
too subtle choice of words in the spec. The distinction is exactly the sort
of nit-picky thing that the Sun Java Programmer Certification exam looks for
understanding of.

For the original question, I think the major reason for avoiding the nested
static class on any significant size project is practicality (concrete
separation of concerns), e.g.:

- Developers and QA may both be writing unit level tests, depending how the
work effort is partitioned (I've worked on some medium sized projects where
this was the case). In which case, you want the tests and classes under
test maintained in separate files, possibly separate packages (either for
access reasons or management or code ownership reasons), and possibly
separate directories and/or codebases.

- Keeping tests in the same file as the class under test makes the file size
larger and more difficult to navigate, edit and maintain.

Mike Clark, Eric Vought and other had some other very good reasons along
similar lines.

Scott Stirling
